intro: Ophiorrhiza crispa, commonly known as the hairy sea oats, is a flowering plant species native to coastal regions of Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its small, white flowers and linear, hairy leaves. The plant thrives in sandy or saline soils, often found in mangrove forests and along shorelines. Its unique adaptations allow it to withstand high salinity and tidal influences. Ophiorrhiza crispa plays a role in stabilizing coastal soils and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial organisms.
